Comment: That said, an important footnote to this is that the three-fifths compromise is widely misunderstood. For anybody who isn't actually familiar:  It is correct to point out that considering a person three-fifths of a person is inherently dehumanizing and racist. However, in the context of the debate around Congressional representation, considering slaves full people would have actually been the worse option.  The sticking point was that the slavers wanted to count their enslaved people as part of the population *they* would get to represent. Counting the slaves for representation, while also still considering them property, wasn't giving those slaves any more democratic representation. It was giving their enslavers *extra* representation that they didn't deserve.  Of course, the proper "solution" to the compromise would have been to count them as full people for representation, but then give them voting rights... oh and while we're at it just stop enslaving them in the first place... but what can you do.
